There is no discount. There‚Äôs the same price it is always offered at and there is no time deadline. That‚Äôs called a dark pattern.

Like I said, I do like the app, the concept behind it is great, but the prioritization of monetization over form or function is not a good luck and takes a lot of value away from the app.

title: Simple in good and bad ways.
content:
On the advice of my trainer at the time, I used Fooducate from 2016-2018 and give it credit for helping me understand food, nutrition, and how to properly fuel the body.

In an effort to rebuild my good nutrition habits post pandemic, I once again opted for the Pro subscription to Fooducate in April 2022. The issues started almost immediately.

Despite the persistent 30% discount call-to-action throughout the app, I was charged full pop because I was a prior subscriber. Disappointing, a little bait-and-switchy, but I didn't bother over it much.

Unfortunately, I've had an extremely buggy app experience thereafter. My history would disappear then reappear after a restart. I'd open the app and be treated as a new user, then shut down and log back in to be suddenly remembered. 

Currently I'm logged out of the app and can't login with my Apple ID, and efforts to reset my password have been unsuccessful, apparently due to my admittedly weird ".space" email domain. Good luck finding support on the main website.

I don't doubt that there are legitimate engineering puzzles behind my troubles, but it all seems like a symptom of the app's mid-2010s UX: mobile-only, wonky authentication, and a fuzzy interface compared to MFP, Lifesum, and Noom, to name a few design and functionality leaders.

Thus my relationship with Fooducate comes to an end. Due credit for being in the right place at the right time for my initial nutritional journey, but the competition circa 2022 is more stable, more modern, and just more pleasant to use.

title: A good idea done badly
content: The company seems badly understaffed. Nutrition scores and entries are highly uneven and not apparently made by well-qualified people familiar with current diet and food trends. Lots of items that have been on the grocery store shelf for years are unrecognized in this app but easily found in My Fitness Pal or FitBit. Then the developer wants you to do the work of photographing it and listing all the nutrition info and sending it in. Kind of like paying to have your car repaired at the mechanic‚Äôs shop then being asked by the mechanic to repair it yourself to ‚Äúhelp out‚Äù. Then one must still wait weeks, sometimes months before the info you send in is finally added to the listing. They notify you when they add the info you sent but in many cases it was so long ago I literally had forgotten I sent it. They recently did a (rare) update with major, unneeded, changes to the UI when what they should be doing is getting their listings up-to-date, consistent, and judged by a highly-qualified nutrition expert familiar with today‚Äôs eating and health trends. Then they encouraged feedback about the changes in the update listing *without giving an email address or any other way to give that feedback*. Thus this review. One of my feedback points would have been that they made the main rating score of each item much smaller and harder to read. How is that better? And the new UI requires more clicks to see the same info. How is that better? Why do app developers think ‚Äúimprovement‚Äù just means rearranging the same info but not improving the actual content? It‚Äôs a frustrating app to use in many ways with only glacially slow, haphazard changes that may or may not be improvements. It‚Äôs a really good idea done badly, sorry to say. For example, I like that they actually show a photo of the product. This is better than My Fitness or FitBit and can be a real time saver. But a lot of the photos are so small or dark as to be useless. The search function has long needed upgrading to be more intelligent. I would like to support it with a higher level of membership but I cannot in good conscience pay more for bad service or pay to be asked to do the work the app people should be doing. I would love to see someone take over this app and really execute the ideas well. It could be outstanding.

title: Way more in depth than other calorie counting apps!
content:
I‚Äôve used some other calorie counting apps before, some of them even count macros like Fooducate, but none that I‚Äôve seen offer such an in depth look at what you‚Äôre eating and what it means compared to fooducate. Not only does it outline your calories and macros, it also displays how much of your diet is being comprised of whole, unprocessed foods, grades each individual food choice, and explains every grade and what you need to look out for in your food. The app won‚Äôt just tell you ‚Äúthis product has xanthan gum in it, thumbs down,‚Äù it offers you an answer to ‚Äúwhat the heck is this weird gum and why is it here?‚Äù You might even disagree with some of the grades depending on your preferences and goals, but since all the foods have an explanation you can decide for yourself if you want to disregard that or not. 

The only two reasons I took off a star are: 1) there‚Äôs a pretty prominent community feature but the community appears to be pretty dead. It‚Äôs hard to tell though because some discussions display the date each comment was posted, usually being around 2 years ago or so, and some of them give no indication of how recent it was. 2) there‚Äôs a weird point system that claims to be based off the ‚Äúleading points systems‚Äù (so basically weight watchers but I‚Äôm sure they have reasons to not want to say it) but it seems to have no logical consistency. A bowl of Kale might be three points while a piece of chocolate might only be 1 or 2 sometimes. It‚Äôs generally easy enough to ignore, but these points tend to also be listed on the reasoning for a lower grade on the food which can be mildly bothersome if that‚Äôs not something you‚Äôre trying to consider. 

Overall really great app, I prefer it over my fitness pal and others like it, and I think it could be comparable with a greater, active community.
